deIdi2b2.TEXT:
Record date: 2070-06-10
June 11, 2070
Wanda Koontz, M.D.
Internal Medicine
Barton Memorial Hospital
12 Batchelder Street
Minerva, TN 41694
Re: Jennifer Vance
MR# 542-66-00-3
Dear Wanda:
Mrs. Vance returns for routine follow up. At the present time,
she continues to complain of exertional angina, and states that
she is willing to consider undergoing cardiac catheterization. As
you know, I had suggested this to her last November.
She continues now on a regimen of Atenolol 25 mg p.o. q.d., Paxil
20 mg p.o. q.d., Humalog 10 units sub.q. q.a.m., NPH 25 units
sub.q. q.a.m., sliding scale CZI throughout the day, isosorbide
mononitrate 60 mg p.o. q.d., Pravastatin 20 mg p.o. q.d., Flonase,
Neurontin 300 mg p.o. b.i.d., and Celexa.
Physical exam reveals a thin woman in no acute distress. Blood
pressure right arm sitting 92/60, heart rate 75 and regular.
Respirations 12 and unlabored. Weight 109 pounds. This is one
pound above her weight of six months ago. The neck is supple. JVP
is flat. Carotids with continuing right greater than left bruits.
Chest is clear. Cardiac exam reveals a normal, physiologically
split S2, and a soft systolic ejection murmur radiating from the
apex to the base. No significant diastolic murmur. The abdomen is
benign. Extremities are without edema. The pulses are intact.
Electrocardiogram shows a sinus rhythm at a rate of 75, PR interval
.12, QRS .08, QT .34, axis 75 degrees. There are lateral ST and T
wave changes compatible with strain or ischemia. Compared to her
last electrocardiogram, there has been no significant change.
Impression: Ms. Vance is a 48-year-old woman with a history of
variegata porphyria, insulin dependent diabetes, and significant
Jennifer Vance
MR# 542-66-00-3
June 10, 2070 -2-
coronary artery disease. She is status post intramammary artery
graft to her LAD, after developing restenosis at the site of a
balloon LAD angioplasty. The results of the catheterization will
determine subsequent therapeutic recommendations. She will have
her insulin dose on the morning of her scheduled catheterization.
Thank you very much for allowing me to assist in her care.
Sincerely yours,
Timothy E. Quarterman, M.D.
/quintal
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
